service at nobu is always par none! paired with my favorite standbys here...yellowtail sashimi with jalape\u00f1o!!!! this dish is a signature and is undeniably one of my favorites in the world. super tender and the perfect combination of savory and perfect kick from the fresh jalape\u00f1o! the rock shrimp are just amazing with a creamy sauce and again with a perfect bite at the finish. our server offered a variation of my favorite <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> cod- small portions served on butter lettuce cups that rocked so much i ordered a second. 

for our special adventure we opted for the <mark>Hearts of Palm</mark> pasta- again a kick and for me interesting but not a fav yet clarence loved it! last and should have been first was their <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>- probably the best anywhere , served piping hot and i enjoy it as a finish. 

the wagyu beef was so tempting but i passed. it is hard for me to order a dish equivalent to two new pairs of shoes... honestly we have never been disappointed in a nobu splurge. i was pretty full before the table next to us ordered it and caused me to have food envy but there is always next time. 

aaron was a super knowledgable and very attentive. the team of secondary servers were all on point. huge kudus to the whole team here from start to finish with a standing o for the chef and kitchen too!

went on a solo trip to las vegas and stayed at the hard rock hotel and casino.  thought the nobu was a little out of place there as i had been to the nobu in new york, but decided to give it a try.

ordered a serving of the sake, some <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> cod (apparently a robert deniro favorite) and the omakase.  chef tetsu-san made me an amazing meal tailored to my wishes: mainly uni and toro compositions.  and the great conversation with the two entrepreneurs from jersey beside me made the evening even better.

definitely would give it a try if you are staying at the hard rock.

impromptu trip to vegas for my best friend's birthday! yay! while planning our trip, i noticed a groupon for nobu. i'd been wanting to try out one of the la locations for a while, so this seemed like a win-win. overall, the experience was pretty great. the service was friendly and very attentive (almost too attentive... my ice tea cup was never empty. i don't think they even let it get half empty...)

the meal started with edamame which wasn't anything special. standard at any japanese place you'd go to. the first course was the yellowtail sashimi with jalepeno. this was so good!! i'm normally not a jalepeno fan, but it had just the right amount of kick to it. this was definitely my favorite dish of the night.

next up was the rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>. this was alright. i liked the sauce with the lettuce/salad below, but it was too heavy for the shrimp... my friend and i agreed that it just left us craving honey walnut shrimp from panda express. 

third entree up was the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>. this was also an outstanding dish, like the yellowtail. the fish was cooked perfectly and the entire dish was both presented well and tasted great. 

the fourth entree (and the reason for docking one star) was california roll and assorted nigiri. maybe it's just because i live in la and i'm spoiled by great sushi, but i wasn't impressed. the fish was fresh enough, but definitely not up to par to say, sugarfish. and at the heart of it all, nobu is a japanese restaurant, so i expected their sushi to be on par with their fusion dishes. sadly, not the case.

the meal ended with the <mark>Bento Box</mark> dessert, which had flour-less chocolate cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> cappuccino thing. i'm not a huge dessert person but it was ok. i've never disliked any green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> i've had and the cappuccino thing was unique. 

overall, it was a great meal and good experience. without a doubt, it was worth the price of the groupon. not sure about full price though. i think only the yellowtail sashimi and <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> would be worth it.

i came back four years later and this place is still so good! so good that i went twice in one week which is very unusual for me especially with all the great places vegas has to offer. the items that stuck out for me were the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> (simple but omg all the flavors work so well together...and that sauce that it comes with is delicious), <mark>Salmon / Salmon Belly</mark>,  <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>, <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark>, <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>, and the kronuts! and the service was absolutely impeccable!

my first time at this nobu. i normally use the ceasars one in vegas. devine as expected. my absolute favourite place. you can't get better <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> anywhere!!!!! this restaurant executes everything perfectly. i never have anything but positive comments. thank you once again for making my visit amazing!! until next time.

amazing. let me list what i would suggest:

-sake 35 is super smooth
-sake 40
-chicken & steak skeweres are amazing
-sakito peppers instead of edamame 
- <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>
-<mark>Spicy Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> hand roll

however, if i was to name one thing off the menu to eat and only eat that it would be the black mod soaked in miso for a few days. it is amazing. my boyfriend thought i was crazy for ordering this dish, and ended up eating half. 

after our initial entree orders, we ordered more sashimi toro because the fish literally melted in your mouth it was so delicious.



ask for marcus he is the shit!!!! he took care of us even though he wasn't our waiter. we ended up ordering another fresh-to order plate of shasimi with him.

a true gem at the hard rock.
you tell the waiter what your price limit per person is and he brings out shareable dishes to accommodate. everything, and i mean everything that he brought out was finger licking good!
the miso on the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> was the best i've ever had, ever. the tuna tar tar.. wow. they brought out the sushi dishes at the end but everything prior was better.
highly highly recommend going to this spot.

authentic japanese food...no, but really good modern japanese food.
<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> - everytime i order this dish.  probably could eat 3 plates
<mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> - excellent but you better eat it with rice or share it  because the miso can become overwhelming.  but that could've been the 4 bottles of grey goose the night before speaking.
<mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark> - tasty but salty, again good sharing.
creamy rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> - excellent.
blue fin toro <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark> - excellent.
blue fin toro <mark>Cabbage Steak with Truffles</mark> - it was a special at the time and not really worth the $100 for 6 pieces.  just order blue fin toro sushi, sometimes simple is better.
would venture here every other trip to lv.  haven't tried other nobus to compare but will get a chance in the bahamas.

it was a hit-and-miss experience at nobu in vegas.

hits: <mark>Mixed Seafood Ceviche</mark>, sweet <mark>Shrimp</mark> - <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> sashimi, kumamoto oysters <mark>Kumamoto Oyster with <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark></mark>, <mark>Lobster <mark>Tuna <mark>King Crab <mark>Vegetable <mark>Salmon Nobu Style Taco</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark>, bluefin tuna tartar <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark>, and tiradito <mark>Scallop</mark>.

misses: black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>, <mark>House Special</mark> deluxe roll, fried mai with sweet butter sauce.

personal favorites are bluefin tuna tartar and sweet <mark>Shrimp</mark> - <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> sashimi. presentation and tastes of these two plates are superb and i have never had before. you will be craving for more after you finish the tuna tartar, which are sized like your pinky; you will keep sucking the shrimp tails to get the last piece out.

the reason of my miss experience is that we trusted the waiter's recommendations and ordered the cooked food. to be honest, i strongly advise everyone to stay away from the cook food. if you want to be full, go across the street and get a burger after. this place is pricey and you definitely like to spend your money wisely on the right stuff.

p.s. i have not had the opportunity to have hamachi jalapeno and cannot offer any comment. however, i know a place in san francisco offers a very similar dish and it was quite good, if not great.

ate at nobu in vegas last night and what an amazing experience we had.  we had the omakase experience, started with cold dishes to warm entree to heavy appetizer and finished off with a few of their special <mark>Dessert</mark>.  starters: <mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> sashimi with dried miso, olive oil and yuzu; <mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> and cilantro; <mark>Scallop</mark> and <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> lettuce wraps; pink snapper with pineapple and tomatoes. for warm dishes: chilean sea bass <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> crust and <mark>Tenderloin of Beef</mark> braised <mark>Kumamoto Oyster with <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark></mark> on a bed of south american yam; <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> presented in 3 different sauces.  to finish off the meal, chelf sent a platter of 4 special <mark>Dessert</mark>.  always make room for dessert!!!

hands down, best sushi chain. top notch quality fish/dishes and pretty pricey. but who cares when you're on the strip; expensive is expected. :p 

nobu stands out from the rest of the sushi chains because of their creative entrees. based off their chilean sea bass and black cod dishes, i'm quite impressed and have confidence that any of their dishes would be a good pick. these dishes were well prepared and were not drenched <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark>. their raw fish tastes as if it's fresh from the ocean; definitely close to what you can get in japan. however, the quality of their fish is what closely resembles japan not the restaurant itself as their menu, interior decor and waitstaff is like any other american restaurant.

best. sushi. experience. of. my. life.

wow, that is all i can say. each and every dish tried was to die for. 

don't get me wrong, it cost us a fortune- we had a large group and they serve small plates. so naturally we ordered a lot of plates. but i swear, it is worth splurging here.

we had an awesome waiter! he was funny, friendly, and made great recommendations. he advised us on how to use the menu and where to start. 

our favorite dishes were the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, and one more sashimi dish (i can't remember what it was called!) they were perfectly simple and fresh. they weren't drenched <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark> like many other sushi bars you experience. i'm pretty sure i could have eaten this for the rest of my life. 

try it. it's worth the money.

it is hard to find good quality fish in las vegas being that we live in a desert and our nearest lake is radioactive. but nobu manages to find some high quality and good tasting fish. so far this is the only japanese restaurant in a casino that i have actually liked.  

the bluefin toro tartar was really fatty which i love and it was sitting in a wasabi sauce that was amazing. with the caviar on top it is one of the single best bites of food i have had. 

if you go i would stick to the specialty items on the menu and not order the sushi. you can get near equal quality sushi for less money at other places and it will fill you up faster so you wont get to enjoy their menu as much. also, the black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> was sooooooo good. the fish melted in my mouth and didnt fall apart when i put a fork to it. 

the saki selection is small but the ones we tried were great.

the lack of 5 stars is due to the fact that we ordered <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> was soaked <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark> and there was no resemblance of fish in the dish. everything else we had we loved though.

after our free pitbull concert from one of our work vendors, we were hungry!  for appetizers, we decided to go to the culinary dropout, so for dinner, we decided to go to the next restaurant, nobu.  i've heard amazing things about this place and knew that it was top notch.  heck, i've seen it on keeping up with the kardashians. as good as i know the food would be, i also knew the price tag would be pretty hefty!

when we got in, i noticed and array of seating.  chairs, tables, booths, bar, you name it.  the green back splash of the bar really went well with the light colored wood framing around the rest of the restaurant. you felt like you were at a super trending japanese restaurant.  it just felt high end!  our server was nice, but knew we had a bunch to drink.  we put our menu in his hands.  here's what we got (with prices):

-<mark>Kumamoto Oyster with <mark>Bone in Ribeye 24oz Nobu Sauce</mark></mark>  18
-<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>  24
-<mark>Uni or Oyster Shooter</mark>  12
-salmon sashimi   24
-<mark>Mixed Seafood Ceviche</mark>  22
-<mark>Snow Crab</mark> <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>  28
-tuna (big eye) sushi 12
-salmon sushi 10
-yellowtail sushi 12

some of these items came in a sushi platter.  i wasn't too sure how the platting and combination went.  all i know is the fish was super fresh.  the aesthetics of each plate was like a work of art.  i felt like i was a kardashian! lol.  our total bill for 7 people, came to $780. oh-em-gee!  for a nice, elegant night, to me, this was worth it.  such amazing food and great atmosphere.  i will definitely return!

three words: miso black cod.

oh my gawd. 

if you have to choose only 2 items from the menu, it would be the miso black cod and the miso black cod.  this is not to say that the other dishes aren't as fabulous - i would definitely recommend the chilean sea bass with dried miso, <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark>, broiled tassie  trout, and <mark>Beef Kushiyaki</mark>.  

the cherry on top is the service - from the first phone call to reserve a table for 10 for a friday night dinner (made a day prior due to a reservation cock-up at social house), subsequent phone calls to organize the delivery of birthday cake, and the servers during the dinner.  

all these made us forget about the $8 cake-cutting fee which, while ridiculous, is somewhat justified.  

the damage report came to about $70 per person.  money well spent, no less.

i have always wanted to try nobu and finally went! and it was worth the wait let me tell you! we went for my bday and did not have a reservation. we got there pretty early around 5ish so they were able to sit us without a res. our waiter jeffrey was on point. best service. he recommended we start with the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>. it was melt in my mouth amazing. i could live off the dish for the rest of my life. lol. it was yellowtail with the right amount of sweetness and spice. we also got the cucumber salad which was pretty good. a lot of the vinegar did go to the bottom of the bowl which made it hard to coat your salad but it was still good. we also had a sear salmon sashimi which i do not remember the name that was excellent. we got spicy edamame, <mark>Beef Kushiyaki</mark>, the black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> and the wagyu beef gyoza. the cod was really good and highly recommended. the wagyu beef was great with two dipping sauces. we literally could have kept ordering food. we had a couple of nice cocktails as well. 

after dinner they brought us out a plate with happy birthday with a choc cake and green <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. we also ordered the whiskey moose. both <mark>Dessert</mark> were to die for and i was in heaven. 

what a fun place to go. you have people dressed to the max, casual people, people from all over the world that come and eat here. come chow down some amazing eats, listen to some funky music and watch the beautiful people. yes please!

this is where i would take points away:

amazing!!! were the first words i thought of when i was dining and leaving this restaurant.  my best friend recommended this restaurant as we were planning our vegas trip.  i didn't think much about this place when he brought it up, my expectations were pretty much non-existent.  once we got to the restaurant, it was top notch from start to finish.  we ordered quite a bit of different dishes and it was delicious down to the last bite.  our waiter was quite helpful with our decision making and recommendations.  first dish on our table was the fresh <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>.  this dish is awesome!  the flavoring along with the fresh yellowtail easily makes this my favorite dish at this restaurant.  we also had the monkfish pate, <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>, black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>, broiled yellowtail collar; <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark>, rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> and creamy spicy sauce.  all around delicious dishes with great visual presentation.  their lychee martini is also worth a mention, a tasty treat.  i highly recommend this restaurant for those who haven't tried it yet.  this is easily one of my top 10 restaurants.  just a wonderful experience from beginning to finish!

the visit was on a labor day sunday around 6pm.  the last visit to this particular nobu was back in 2003 when i didn't know the difference between a piece of foie and a rubber sole.  i recall having the chef special back then as well, but the omakase this time was definitely more enjoyable.  this was probably due to the fact that i wasn't three sheets to the wind this time.  being married does these things.

there were those that chose the bronze omakase ($100) and those that went for the silver ($150) like yours truly, and boy was there ever a difference.  there were major discrepancies between the cuts and also the types of meats served.  the sashimi and the speciality dishes also had noticeable differences.  it's not to say that the 100 dollar omakase wasn't good, but it wasn't great...at least from my vantage point.

there's about a zillion details i will be leaving out, such as the dried flakes of hoo-haa sprinkled with a drizzle of the thinger thang.  so use your imagination..

course 1 - a bonito sashimi.
course 2 - amaebi splashed with hot oil, chawan mushi with truffle and crab eggs at the bottom, kampachi sashimi with dried miso flakes.
course 3 - toro sashimi <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> ginger sauce <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> sauce topped with a bunch of edible flowers which made it all purdy and crap.
course 4 - seared <mark>Scallop</mark> on a bed of sea beans.
course 5 - kobe beef (served medium) with pan fried <mark>Teppan Style Foie Gras</mark>.
course 6 - sushi set (nigiri) <mark>Inaniwa Pasta with Lobster</mark> broth and <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark>.  the set consisted of - toro, abalone, spanish mackerel, eel, tai (<mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark>) and tamago.
course 7 - an array of sweets including <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, chocolate looking souffle thing, fresh fruits and other sugary confections we couldn't stay for because we were already late for the friggin cirque du pouffay show.

..

all in all, a great meal.  i enjoyed the silver omakase at matsuhisa better, the wife liked this dinner much better.  definitely a strong 4 star, but nowhere near a five.  the highlight of the meal for me was the foie served over the kobe.  the dish was so luxurious i really was at a loss for words as i was enjoying every delectable bite.  the slice of black truffle in the chawan mushi gives you a big mule kick in the face which was in short, heavenly.  

i was surprised to find that i liked the non sushi dishes better than the raw, but is it such a huge surprise?  we live in cities like la, sf, ny, etc. where quality ingredients are so readily available.  i've had sashimi as good if not better in other restaurants.  most don't serve it with the detail and ingenuity like mr. nobu matsuhisa, but it takes way too much money to surprise this sushi cowboy.

i truly don't mean to sound snobbish, but there's only so many ways to serve up a nice slab of toro.  i'm more impressed these days by the way chefs serve up foie.  and i am totally infatuated with bone marrow.

..

i've said too much.  

i am off to eat.

if it were only about the sushi, nobu would get 5 stars from me. but, i knock off 2 stars for service. we walked in on a saturday night and got seats at the sushi bar, which is the place to be. we went with our sushi chef's suggestions, which were nobu's <mark>House Special</mark>, including "new-style sashimi." these consist of the best fish, <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark>, with delicate sauces and garnishes: <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, live octopus with a peruvian chili paste, whitefish and salmon <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce, tuna <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>-mustard sauce. everything was first-class, including the junmai daiginjo sake.

then, i ordered the <mark>Bento Box</mark> chocolate cake dessert. we were told it would take 8 minutes to cook. no problem - our bellies were happily full of sashimi. 20 minutes later, however, still no dessert, and we finally were able to flag someone down to check on it. another ten minutes went by. our waiter then came out to tell us there was a mixup in the kitchen and our cake went to another table. he tried to give us a plateful <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> to tide us over - this didn't go over well, as the last thing we wanted was to eat a plateful <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> and then a chocolate cake. another ten minutes or so, the dessert came out. it was excellent, but frankly wasn't worth waiting over half an hour for. we ask ed for the check while still eating...took another ten minutes...gave the credit card and another ten minutes went by...waiter came out to tell us the credit card isn't clearing and do we want to give another card? by this point, well over an hour had gone by since dessert was ordered and we just wanted to leave already. 

when our check finally arrived, they did charge us for the dessert that took over 30 minutes to arrive at our table. when i mentioned this to the server, he took it right off the bill. but i was miffed that i even had to ask - the right thing to do would have been to take it off in the first place.

too bad, since up until we ordered dessert we were very pleased with the sushi our wonderful chef served us. even for a saturday night in vegas, the service was unacceptably unresponsive for such a high-end restaurant.

i spent a week in las vegas at the hard rock hotel for nye this year. it was not my first visit to nobu, so we were very much looking forward to a meal there.

as always, it was fantastic. the cucumber martini was so very refreshing i am still craving it. the yellow tail <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> has the best citrus soy sauce - we actually came back & got a drink & this dish again before we went out another night because it was so good & light. we also had the <mark>Lobster <mark>Tuna <mark>King Crab <mark>Vegetable <mark>Salmon Nobu Style Taco</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> which were great.

i ate here for a business dinner and sat at one of the tables but ordered omakase from the sushi bar.

my colleagues and i went big and went with $150 a person so we had high expectations...

i will try my best to remember everything that came out...(not in order)

the first dish was a salmon trout sahimi with ikura eggs inside.  the fish had some chewy veins in it, and there wasn't any type of sauce on it - i guess we were supposed to enjoy the 2 components together.

there was a dish of fatty tuna (otoro) on top of a rock salt.  this was unique and the fish was melty

there was a <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark> type dish that came out that used delicious dashi broth - anyone who understands umami would've enjoyed this

kobe beef with special mayo sauce was good, but nothing spectacular

<mark>Scallop</mark> in a green guacamole sauce was edible, but the balance wasn't completely there

kanpachi <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> was good too but trendy

in the end, a full platter of sushi came with the trademark "nobu" mark on the egg sushi - this was perhaps the most dissapointing.  the fish tasted bland, the rice was somewhat hardened like it was sitting out for a while, and i really would've liked to end the night on a high note but this last platter of mediocre sushi ended the night on a low note

however on the plus side the service is excellent - the servers are all very attentive.  and the atmosphere, being inside the hard rock hotel, is hip and lively.

unbelievable meal. would not recommend getting sushi here the cooked dishes are definitely the way to go. sushi was pretty standard but very expensive.  i was not wowed by the quality of the fish and considering the price i think there are better spots for sushi.  the fried snapper, chili paste and truffle oil edamame, hamachi <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce,  and <mark>Crab <mark><mark>XO and Jamon Iberico</mark> <mark>Beef <mark>Crab Fried Rice</mark></mark></mark></mark> balls with <mark>Spicy Tuna (Big Eye)</mark>. were some of my favorite dishes.

usually when a restaurant has this much hype i'm disappointed.  it's hard to live up to hype.
i'm happy to report...no disappointment here!

we had dinner there last night.  our server was thomas and he could not have been better.  one of the best servers we've ever had.  he was friendly, on top of it and fantastic about explaining the restaurant, menu, food and the area the food comes from.

we went for sushi, but after thomas explained the menu we realized we should be eating what the restaurant does best.  so glad that we did!

we had...
*yellowtail sashimi with jalepeno.  amazing.  this was my favorite dish of the night.  i want to eat it every day.

*broiled yellowtail collar.  delightful!
*<mark>Mixed Seafood Ceviche</mark>.  my husband loved this, i thought it was just okay.  i think it was just my taste though, i don't love cucumbers or octopus.

i must admit, i have not been to a nobu that i didn't like.  so yes, i am a fan of this high-end japanese chain restaurant.  we had dinner here this past friday night.  unfor<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> i am not fond of the hotel that it's located in... which is barely a step up from a hooters-type ambiance with the class-less tatted out clientele and their hoochie mama's attached to their hips.  well back in the day hard rock was the place to go to... but that was years ago.  so the fact that one has to step foot into the hard rock casino to get into the entrance of this restaurant... should really get a minus star for not strategically relocating this at a more ritzy hotel casino like bellagio or cosmopolitan.   

we started off with cocktails... lychee martini and a greyhound... can't go wrong there.  as for the app...started off with the sea salted warm edemame.  i was so hungry, i practically ate all the soy beans.  i ordered the yummy <mark>Kelp Salad</mark> and he ordered hamachi sashimi with jalepeno... so perfectly fresh <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce or miso... so good!  he ordered the <mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> was sinfully delicious... (fried so not a healthy choice).  and i ordered the chilean sea bass with dried miso... my all time favorite, which did not disappoint!  salmon, hamachi and unagi sushi... small but still so good.  and we ended with yet another cocktail :-) and the <mark>Bento Box</mark>.... flourless chocholate cake with white chocolate sauce and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>... omg!  amazing dinner with outstanding service.  yes nobu is expensive but i was for<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> that he was so generous... so not really sure what our bill was... but so worth every bite.

several different nobu locations worldwide and the us. this nobu is located inside hard rock hotel - the first one in vegas (and the better one). i had one of my birthday celebrations here.

we got <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark> tataki <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark>, chocolate banana martini, lychee martini, <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>, <mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> sauce, <mark>Tenderloin of Beef</mark> toban yaki, nobu's <mark>House Special</mark>, <mark>Salmon Skin</mark> handroll, kulfi and my birthday "<mark>Bento Box</mark>".

sashimi and <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>:
the fish here is generously cut.  they're fresh and the sauces they come with accent the fish. 5/5

<mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> sauce:
if you like garlic and a little bit of spiciness - this is the dish for you.  the garlic sauce was amazing. the dish comes <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> mushrooms. 5/5
