the bar for nobu was set pretty high after trying the full omakase experience at kabuto the night before.  i did my yelp homework and scoured previous reviews, making note of the oft recommended items, and went in knowing exactly what my friend and i would order.

we ordered a gamut of different dishes: <mark>Shishito Peppers</mark>, edamame, wagyu beef, jalape\u00f1o yellowtail, rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>, lamp chop, otoro and salmon sashimi, miso black cod. 

i thought i was assembling a nobu all-star meal; what we ended up with was a mediocre and extremely overpriced meal.  for every dish that we  ordered, i could list a superior counterpart at japonais or sunda in chicago for a fraction of the cost.

also of note is the fact that our waiter initially remarked that sashimi orders came as two pieces, but when we got our bill, we noted that our four bite-sized slices of otoro came to a total of $76.  the wagyu was also incredibly overpriced for what we got; apparently each ounce is $30 or so and the minimum order is 2 ounces.  

maybe it was the sheer excellence of the previous night's meal, but we left feeling we had blown $350 on a very unsatisfactory experience.  even at half the price, the value would be questionable.

we love going to nobu and have been to many locations all over.  we had a party of ten so i got to try many things on the menu:

rock shrimp - always delicious
<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> - yum
ceviche taco - yum
<mark>Imported Wagyu <mark>Lobster <mark>Tuna <mark>King Crab <mark>Vegetable <mark>Salmon Nobu Style Taco</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark>- yum
<mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>- okay, nothing special
wagyu dumplings- amazing
yamakazi sidecar- drink was pretty yummy
chilean sea bass <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>- ok- should have ordered the black cod
dessert was the chefs tasting platter- this was the best part of dinner! 

decor was dated- not up to current lv standards. next time we will go to the new location at caesars palace

service was mediocre. not sure what was up with the waiter. he was barely seen. we had to order from 3 different waiters because ours was nowhere to be found. it was my sister's 21st bday and we wanted to make it a special dinner, but it felt like we were ignored. thank you to the manager for making up for it.

overall, i'm still a big fan of nobu, but will not return to this location.

7/2: nobu hard rock rivals yellowtail @bellagio as my all-time favorite restaurant. i've been here one previous time and i don't remember much, but nothing bad. i just kept comparing it to my favorite, which is kind of unfair. however, this time was different...very memorable in a good way. 

my server gordon and his waitstaff team's service was amazing! i had the locals tasting menu ($75) and it was worth every penny. every dish was cordially described in just the right amount of detail before being served. all questions were answered in a friendly manner. the atmosphere was very nice and classy as well. beautiful decor. 

-kobe beef taco (as an appetizer, separate from tasting menu)...best taco ever! beef was soft and moist

-<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> (best sashimi i've ever had by far! so soft and fresh. price tag aside, i could go for 10 of these plates! though that might be too much of a good thing)
-tuna <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark> (love it. best tuna ever) 
-rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with creamy spicy (best shrimp ever...you're getting the point! i didnt know shrimp could taste this good) 
-<mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> (this and the yellowtail sashimi were my favorite dishes...high praise for these 2 seems to be the trend based off of many reviews. definitely no disagreement here. best fish ever! if you are ordering one item, i highly recommend it) 
-assorted sushi and <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark> (basics but pretty good. large <mark>Scallop</mark> were <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the soup. unique taste and interesting twist compared to standard <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>. delicious!) 
-dessert (strawberry, vanilla, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>)...all were great. not really a complaint, but a variety of <mark>Dessert</mark> is preferred. im sure they would be amazing like everything else as well.

thank you nobu, for one of the best dining experiences ever. i will definitely be back!
excellent service, loved the food. highlights were rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>, yellowtail jalape\u00f1o sashimi.

five stars for the experience!! the atmosphere was great and the food was delicious...
however the portions are extremely small and in my opinion not worth the $$! 
i enjoyed my pineapple martinis, <mark>Uni or Oyster Shooter</mark>, yellowtail/jalapeno rolls, <mark>Scallop</mark>, cucumber salad and <mark>King Crab <mark>Vegetable <mark>Salmon Nobu Style Taco</mark></mark></mark>
***however***
i left hungrier than when i arrived!
9/21/13

authentic japanese food...no, but really good modern japanese food.
<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> - everytime i order this dish.  probably could eat 3 plates
<mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> - excellent but you better eat it with rice or share it  because the miso can become overwhelming.  but that could've been the 4 bottles of grey goose the night before speaking.
<mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark> - tasty but salty, again good sharing.
creamy rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> - excellent.
blue fin toro <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark> - excellent.
blue fin toro <mark>Cabbage Steak with Truffles</mark> - it was a special at the time and not really worth the $100 for 6 pieces.  just order blue fin toro sushi, sometimes simple is better.
would venture here every other trip to lv.  haven't tried other nobus to compare but will get a chance in the bahamas.

just got back from another great vegas weekend. though i have been to nobu here many times, i have never given them a review. long overdue. the good news is that with the opening of the "new" place at ceasars, the hard rock location is very easy to get a table now (hope they stay here ;) )
the service is always top notch. the food still retains a very high quality. my favs did not dissapoint, the spicy rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>, the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> and the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> cod were perfection. can't wait for my next vegas trip!

this is the only restaurant that i would recommend at the hard rock hotel. i was working at the hrh for five days and ended up eating at almost every establishment there. nobu is the only one that i would optionally go to again.

this is the best sushi i've had. everything was flavorful and top quality. i can't remember all the dishes i had, but below are the ones i can remember (score out of 5):

-bug <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark> lotus chips 4
-<mark>Shishito Peppers</mark> 2 (i got a really spicy one!)
-<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> 4
-rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with creamy spicy sauce 4 (butter ponzu sauce 3)
-rice cubes <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark> spread 3
-sushi roll with 4 types of fish 5
-<mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> 10 you must get this, it is sooooo good!
-horchata flan 3

i would go just for the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>!

the food is great, but the service was lacking. when we sat down we were a group of 5 and a 6th person joined us. when the waiter brought the tuna lotus chips out he said there are only 5 since that's how many you were when you sat down. he easily could have said i'll bring you another, but i had to specifically ask him. for the price, service should be better, maybe because it's still in the hard rock.

perfection. i love sushi and have been to several nobu restaurants (both new york locations, san diego, bahamas, los angeles) and this place is my favorite. i've been to this nobu over 10 times and look forward to returning. 

the food at any nobu is consistently out of this world but what makes this location my favorite is the staff. not only can each staff member be a model but everyone on staff is attentive, efficient, and interesting. 

things to order:

last time we were in we had andrew as our server. super great guy. he gave us some excellent recommendations and was very friendly and professional. i'm going to request to sit in andrew's section every time i go back. 

of course i wish nobu wasn't so expensive but i still think it's well worth every penny.

so- we utilized a tasting menu purchase from groupon, and my biggest fear was that it was not going to be enough food...far from it! the dishes are all good-sized portions (frankly, more food than myself and my boyfriend would normally eat) and everything was delicious! some, more than others- the actual sushi roll was a little forgettable, but the following were amazing: yellowtail sashimi with jalape\u00f1o, rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with creamy spicy sauce, black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>. also, the desert was delicious. 

i would recommend, however pricing is not for the faint of heart. it is pricey- but, i think anyone attending this establishment should know that.

this is a review of the groupon deal dinner.

the skinny: fusion peruvian japanese dishes left me unimpressed (3) service: excellent service despite the disappointing cuisine (5) value: for the groupon, it is still overpriced for what it is. so you can imagine what i have to say about full price ... not worth it (2.5).

so here's the deal. we spotted the nobu groupon for $95/2 person (regularly $150) prix fixe menu and we thought "how can we pass this up?".

we went and were seated prompty. our server was great at giving us time and space to make some decisions on the menu. we ended up getting in <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the prix fixe an order of their <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> to round out the menu. the specials that they offered didn't really appeal - there was a lot of fruit/candied nuts mixed in with sashimi which sounded overly sweet to me so i passed on those.

starting <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> simple edamame with maldon sea salt (love those flakes!), it was a nice way to start a meal.

course 1) <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>/cilantro (6 slices): this was a good dish but not exceptional. although i have had different versions of this before, this is one of the better renditions given the quality of the fish and the strategically correct amount of heat. my only thing with this dish was the actual slices of sashimi itself - the slices were a bit thin and ragged along the edges which surprised me given the supposed caliber of this place.

course 2) selection of nigri (6 pcs) and a california roll (6 pcs): the nigri was okay - the slices of fish were decent sized. i was despondent when i realized that the sushi rice was a little too overcooked and sticky.

course 3) rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>: the first bite was good however as we ate, the spicy aioli began to slowly permeate the batter leading to a soggier batter. i think it aioli would have been better served as a dipping sauce rather than dressed on the tempura to retain textural integrity. flavorwise, this was a nice dish and we loved the mixture of chive and togarashi.

course 4) miso glazed black cod: candied black cod more like it! overly sweet, the piece of fish was smothered in the sugary sauce which became more unappetizing the more we worked to finish this. i have made this at home using his recipe with 1/2 the sugar and it is much better.

course 5) <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> (<mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the groupon): the tempura was okay nothing special. the batter was slightly spongier than what i like. i think it would have been better if the shredded daikon/ginger was provided to us so we could <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> much/little we wanted.

course 6) normally this would be <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> except it was my birthday so i got a molten cake with a tiramisu and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. all of them were very good however there was nothing that really wow'ed me to think that it was exceptional.

perhaps 10 years ago, the level of this fusion cuisine would be considered cutting edge. however time has made his dishes appear quite dated. the signature dishes of rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>/yellowtail jalape\u00f1o sashimi/miso glazed black cod are easily found elsewhere - one might argue that this location's rendition is rather lackluster considering the price. given the many issues with the dishes mentioned above, i cannot recommend this place given the groupon price let alone full price. although our server was truly exceptional, that doesn't make up for the food. 2.5 rounded up to 3 starred review.

the absolute best experience ever. had the groupon - filled us up completely and blew our minds with every dish. the service is outstanding and we were in and out in an hour. had edamame to start - a good primer. then yellowtail sashimi with jalape\u00f1os and a special soy sauce - oh my goodness my favorite dish. i don't even like sashimi. then a huge california roll and tons of nigri - best i've ever had. then this crazy <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with the greatest sauce ever over a bed of lettuce with my best - tasting dressing that complimented it so well - like fireworks in your mouth. very filling. then this fish. alaskan cod. i thought there was a party in my mouth - cooked absolutely perfectly it melted in your mouth and left you feeling completely satisfied. dessert was insane. you just have to experience it.

my sister and i planned out our trip to vegas to include a dinner at nobu. maybe my tastes are horrible and i'm missing out on some great dishes, but i found our dining experience to be a-ok.

the service was great; the staff is very knowledgeable about the menu. of course, the prices are up there--not complaining about that part. but in all honesty, i really didn't taste a different in the quality of fish used in my sushi compared to the less than $10 rolls i eat here in az. same goes with the rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> in creamy spicy sauce. at least i can say i've tried it.

i have been to numerous nobu's across the country and have almost never been disappointed. the nobu at the hard rock get's it right.
the service was top notch, they made you feel welcome.
the food was typical nobu. it was fantastic.
taco are amazing, we always get <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> tuna, they had cerviche tacos which i never seen on a nobu menu, they were great. <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark>, miso cod rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> ,<mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> and there special steak with a truffle sauce.
we were not disappointed with any dish.
there is a reason that nobu's is my wife's favorite restaurant.
they are always consistent.
i can't wait to back again.

impromptu trip to vegas for my best friend's birthday! yay! while planning our trip, i noticed a groupon for nobu. i'd been wanting to try out one of the la locations for a while, so this seemed like a win-win. overall, the experience was pretty great. the service was friendly and very attentive (almost too attentive... my ice tea cup was never empty. i don't think they even let it get half empty...)

the meal started with edamame which wasn't anything special. standard at any japanese place you'd go to. the first course was the yellowtail sashimi with jalepeno. this was so good!! i'm normally not a jalepeno fan, but it had just the right amount of kick to it. this was definitely my favorite dish of the night.

next up was the rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>. this was alright. i liked the sauce with the lettuce/salad below, but it was too heavy for the shrimp... my friend and i agreed that it just left us craving honey walnut shrimp from panda express. 

third entree up was the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>. this was also an outstanding dish, like the yellowtail. the fish was cooked perfectly and the entire dish was both presented well and tasted great. 

the fourth entree (and the reason for docking one star) was california roll and assorted nigiri. maybe it's just because i live in la and i'm spoiled by great sushi, but i wasn't impressed. the fish was fresh enough, but definitely not up to par to say, sugarfish. and at the heart of it all, nobu is a japanese restaurant, so i expected their sushi to be on par with their fusion dishes. sadly, not the case.

the meal ended with the <mark>Bento Box</mark> dessert, which had flour-less chocolate cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> cappuccino thing. i'm not a huge dessert person but it was ok. i've never disliked any green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> i've had and the cappuccino thing was unique. 

overall, it was a great meal and good experience. without a doubt, it was worth the price of the groupon. not sure about full price though. i think only the yellowtail sashimi and <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> would be worth it.

i had wanted to try nobu for some time, having heard many good things about it. when i saw the $99 groupon plus the 20% off groupon was offering plus my wife's b'day to celebrate there, i knew the stars were aligned.  could it live up to reputation?
the food: the groupon is for a 5 course tasting menu. the meal starts with a pass out of edamame with maldon salt. a very generous portion and an excellent way to start a meal. the first course was yellowtail tuna <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> and cilantro. the tuna was sliced super thin and was in a citrus sauce. it was very tasty and different than yellowtail that i have eaten at my local sushi restaurant. things got even better after that. the next dish was rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with a creamy spicy sauce. wow, was that good! not like any tempura i have eaten before. very lightly breaded, cooked so the shrimp were soft but not mushy. and the spicy sauce was easily handled even by my gringo palate. a great dish. and a huge portion. by its size, the dish would have been enough for dinner if it was the only thing served. this was followed by the alaskan black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>. another outstanding dish. the fourth course was the sushi; tuna, fluke and salmon with a california roll. this was the weakest part of the menu - only very good. last course, dessert. i photographed the plate. a beautiful presentation with very tasty treats (and a hand written birthday greeting in chocolate). the food rates 5 stars plus.
the service: as soon as we were seated, our server, albert, came by to greet us, explain the tasting menu, and take our drink orders. throughout the meal, he, the busboy, and the food runner were very attentive without being overbearing. they made us feel very welcome. our water glasses were never allowed to go below half full. the table was cleared promptly. the food came out of the kitchen plated beautifully. the service was 5 stars plus.
the ambiance: the restaurant is nicely decorated with lots of bamboo. however, the tables for 2 were placed one on top of the other. we were there on a monday night, so the tables were never more than 1/3 full.  but our table was about 6 inches from the next table, which was 6 inches from the next in a line up of 4 tables. if the restaurant were crowded and there were people at the next table, we would have been eating with strangers. not my idea of a celebration/romantic meal. at best, 3 stars for ambiance.
value: $80 for dinner of this quality is the deal of the decade. i would do it again in a heartbeat. but i would never go on a weekend night when the table next to me might be occupied (or i would go with a party of 6 or more - the bigger tables were nicely spaced out).

there's a groupon for nobu?!! whaaaat!?! yes, believe it! i had purchased a groupon for a 5 course tasting menu for $80 for 2 people. and my bf was super excited because he has been wanting to try this place for a while now. it was actually perfect timing that this groupon became available because i was going to be in vegas this weekend. *woot woot!* anyways, i made reservations for 2 at 6pm online and got an e-mail confirmation right away. the groupon can only be used at the nobu inside the hard rock hotel. there's also a nobu inside caeser's palace. once we checked in with the hostesses, we were immediately seated at a nice comfy table and were greeted with a big welcome in japanese! the decor inside was really nice and elegant. i really liked the bamboo wall they had. i also thought it was really cute that we each had a rock on our table used as a chopstick holder. 

ok onto the food! so we started off <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> edamame with sea salt, which was nothing too special but was good. next came the best sashimi i had ever had in my life! its yellowtail sashimi with a jalapeno slice on top dressed in almost like a ponzu sauce. the flavors went really well together and the yellowtail was fresh and spicy. yumm!!! i can probably eat like five more of that dish. :p the next dish was also another one of their popular dishes: the <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>. i was really surprised that the shrimp didn't look at all like the usual tempura found at japanese restaurants. the dish almost looked like honey walnut shrimp actually but tasted ten times better. it was rich and creamy. and the sauce it was covered in was deliscious. next came their black cod dish. my bf absolutely loved this one and i can see why. it was so flakey and cooked to perfection. the fish melted in our mouths like butter and it was sweet and savory. next came a plate of sushi, which consisted of a califonia roll and 6 pieces of sashimi sushi. this dish was nothing too fancy and didn't stand out too much. but it was still tasty. and lastly we got our dessert! it was such a cute looking dessert, which composed of a green tea ice-cream, a flourless chocolate cake, and a cuppacino cup. omg...so good!!! the green tea ice-cream is made in house and  after one bite and you definetely know it's green tea ice-cream. the cuppacino cup was probably my favorite out of the other 2 <mark>Dessert</mark> because it was so beautifully crafted and tasted heavenly. the chocolate cake was very fluffy and not too sweet. overall, everything we tried was excellent! the reason why i subtracted 1 star was because both my bf and i felt that the cod and the shrimp was slightly on the saltier side and all of the dishes are pretty small plates to share between 2 people. otherwise, customer service here was superb and our server was just so friendly and informative on the dishes we were trying. i'm so happy to get to try nobu for the first time! =) so go get your groupon, while it's still available peeps!!

absolutely terrific!  food is always consistent and service is terrific. if there is one knock, it's the atmosphere. tables are a bit squished together and narrow for 2. signature dishes jalape\u00f1o yellowtail, miso salmon <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> shrimp are musts!

impeccable comes to mind when i look back at dinner last night. just wow! 
we started with <mark>Shishito Peppers</mark> and an amazing tuna <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>, moved on to a squid and vegetable dish/casserole that was out of this world followed by miso blackened cod that was absolutely mouth watering.  then came some of the best sushi! yellowtail with scallion roll, yellowtail with jalape\u00f1o roll, <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> roll. the wine was a lovely napa chardonnay. 
the ambiance of this restaurant is calming and the service is excellent! 
japanese restaurants are plentiful in this town so an outstanding stand out restaurant in this category means a lot: this restaurant is outstanding and stands on its own!
the prices are very reasonable. not at all overpriced. highly recommended. i am definitely going back!

for whatever reason, my friend and i felt the need to fly 5+ hours to eat at two restaurants that have locations in ny (nobu and craftsteak), but whatever.  the food here was good, but i felt like the waiter was pushing us to order a ridiculous amount of food which would have been a total waste for my friend and i.  the hamachi <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> appetizer was quite good and of course, i had to order the miso black cod, which was good, but not the best fish i've ever eaten (in fact, the fish my friend got was better.)  the drinks were decent.  all told, a nice meal, but pretty expensive.

the visit was on a labor day sunday around 6pm.  the last visit to this particular nobu was back in 2003 when i didn't know the difference between a piece of foie and a rubber sole.  i recall having the chef special back then as well, but the omakase this time was definitely more enjoyable.  this was probably due to the fact that i wasn't three sheets to the wind this time.  being married does these things.

there were those that chose the bronze omakase ($100) and those that went for the silver ($150) like yours truly, and boy was there ever a difference.  there were major discrepancies between the cuts and also the types of meats served.  the sashimi and the speciality dishes also had noticeable differences.  it's not to say that the 100 dollar omakase wasn't good, but it wasn't great...at least from my vantage point.

there's about a zillion details i will be leaving out, such as the dried flakes of hoo-haa sprinkled with a drizzle of the thinger thang.  so use your imagination..

course 1 - a bonito sashimi.
course 2 - amaebi splashed with hot oil, chawan mushi with truffle and crab eggs at the bottom, kampachi sashimi with dried miso flakes.
course 3 - toro sashimi <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> ginger sauce <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> sauce topped with a bunch of edible flowers which made it all purdy and crap.
course 4 - seared <mark>Scallop</mark> on a bed of sea beans.
course 5 - kobe beef (served medium) with pan fried <mark>Teppan Style Foie Gras</mark>.
course 6 - sushi set (nigiri) <mark>Inaniwa Pasta with Lobster</mark> broth and <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark>.  the set consisted of - toro, abalone, spanish mackerel, eel, tai (<mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark>) and tamago.
course 7 - an array of sweets including <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, chocolate looking souffle thing, fresh fruits and other sugary confections we couldn't stay for because we were already late for the friggin cirque du pouffay show.

..

all in all, a great meal.  i enjoyed the silver omakase at matsuhisa better, the wife liked this dinner much better.  definitely a strong 4 star, but nowhere near a five.  the highlight of the meal for me was the foie served over the kobe.  the dish was so luxurious i really was at a loss for words as i was enjoying every delectable bite.  the slice of black truffle in the chawan mushi gives you a big mule kick in the face which was in short, heavenly.  

i was surprised to find that i liked the non sushi dishes better than the raw, but is it such a huge surprise?  we live in cities like la, sf, ny, etc. where quality ingredients are so readily available.  i've had sashimi as good if not better in other restaurants.  most don't serve it with the detail and ingenuity like mr. nobu matsuhisa, but it takes way too much money to surprise this sushi cowboy.

i truly don't mean to sound snobbish, but there's only so many ways to serve up a nice slab of toro.  i'm more impressed these days by the way chefs serve up foie.  and i am totally infatuated with bone marrow.

..

i've said too much.  

i am off to eat.

edit:

i don't know if it was because we were in vegas, but i felt like everything was a bit contrived.

*shrugs*

i ate here for a business dinner and sat at one of the tables but ordered omakase from the sushi bar.

my colleagues and i went big and went with $150 a person so we had high expectations...

i will try my best to remember everything that came out...(not in order)

the first dish was a salmon trout sahimi with ikura eggs inside.  the fish had some chewy veins in it, and there wasn't any type of sauce on it - i guess we were supposed to enjoy the 2 components together.

there was a dish of fatty tuna (otoro) on top of a rock salt.  this was unique and the fish was melty

there was a <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark> type dish that came out that used delicious dashi broth - anyone who understands umami would've enjoyed this

kobe beef with special mayo sauce was good, but nothing spectacular

<mark>Scallop</mark> in a green guacamole sauce was edible, but the balance wasn't completely there

kanpachi <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> was good too but trendy

in the end, a full platter of sushi came with the trademark "nobu" mark on the egg sushi - this was perhaps the most dissapointing.  the fish tasted bland, the rice was somewhat hardened like it was sitting out for a while, and i really would've liked to end the night on a high note but this last platter of mediocre sushi ended the night on a low note

and the bill at the end was not a pretty sight...

i probably will not go back to nobu again unless it's free.  i was just expecting so much more because of all the hype.  

however on the plus side the service is excellent - the servers are all very attentive.  and the atmosphere, being inside the hard rock hotel, is hip and lively.

i've read about celebrities going to nobu.  my friend talked about nobu like it was a god of sorts.  when we found out we had a table waiting for us at nobu, i was ready to go and feast myself on its delights.  we ordered: the miso black cod, salmon nigiri, a <mark>Soft Shell Crab</mark> roll, the hamachi <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> appetizer, the <mark>Mushroom Salad</mark>, a vegetarian cut roll, and the tiradito.  to drink i had the cucumber martini.  it was seriously one of the best drinks i have ever had.  it tasted like it was made with lychee vodka, and was smooth, refreshing and not too sweet.  unfor<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> our positive experience ended there.  after waiting an hour for our table, we had ordered about 15 cucumber martinis and was dying for some water.  we sat at our table and for 9 people, 2 drink menus were placed on the table and then we were ignored.  i glanced at the menus, waited.  our waiter came by and i asked him for waters all around and food menus.  15 minutes go by.  we had no water, and no menus.  finally, we're given 5 menus for 9 people, as he handed me the last menu, he left saying "we're a little short on menus."  we shared our menus and within 3 minutes he was back asking us what we were going to have.  we asked him for some suggestions, and he pretty much just brushed us off.  we finally ordered the hamachi <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark>.  before i could order anything else, he rushes off.  the next time we saw him he is dropping of a plate of hamachi <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark>.  pretty much the whole night, he just ran off with us halfway through ordering and as a result, we were unable to dine together.  i can only speak for the <mark>Mushroom Salad</mark> and vegetable cut roll.  the vegetable cut roll was pretty good, i mean, steamed <mark>Vegetable</mark>, wrapped in a cucumber wrap, with a little ponzu sauce.  the <mark>Mushroom Salad</mark> was pretty gross.  the mushrooms were varied; trumpets, oysters, shiitake, enoki.  the sauce it was cooked in was sour and as a result made the mushrooms taste bad.  everyone else thought the hamachi <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> were pretty good, and they loved the miso black cod.  everything else, however, they said was mediocre.  mediocreness is ok, if it wasn't coupled with poor service and a $400+ bill.  when the bill came, we inquired about the drinks on the bill as we thought we had taken care of them all at the bar.  his response?  "no you didn't, but you can just take it out of my tip."  i secretly think that everybody raves about this place so much because they don't want to admit they spent that much money on a mediocre experience that you can get anywhere in san francisco for a quarter of the price.  overall verdict:  skip it.  the atmosphere is not really that great, the food isn't really that great, and the service should not be called service.  the pros: the cucumber martini was super good.

so we had reservations for 930 on a friday night and were seated immediately upon our arrival. the (almost all-male)staff were attentive, informative and friendly. 

our meal:

-edamame with shaved seasalt
-sashimi yellowtail <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> (yummmmy, bobby's favorite)
-black cod in lettuce cups with filo flakes (my favorite, so perfect)
-sashimi <mark>Squid 'Pasta' with Light Garlic</mark> chips (little too salty)
-salmon sushi
-toro sushi (very tasty fish)
-dessert: edamame <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> atop a brownsugar brownie,caramel sauce, and tiny sliver of decadent brittle...the <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> scoop was so tiny that we really couldn't taste the edamame. 

a super treat for sushi, but be prepared to spend money!!

seriously delicious!  the first time i went to a sushi place and didn't have any rolls or rice!  we didn't order but had the waiter bring out their best dishes and everything was absolutely amazing!  the cod wraps and crab and rockshrimp were my favorite as well as their signature <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> dish.  they put together a spread of their <mark>Dessert</mark>, so got a little taste of everything.  oh and had the best riesling ever!  i will post pictures of their best dishes!

and even though the chef was busy, he did come out to greet us which was really nice!

i would highly recommend and want to go back!

it was good. it was very, very good. i particularly recommend the tuna <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> sashimi (and i don't normally eat raw fish, but i wasn't going to pass it up this time) and the cod that comes on a lettuce leaf with a little shredded, toasted phyllo on top. 

our waiter was patient with us, and helped us decide even though we were a bit clueless. the service is fast once you make up your mind about what to eat; and we ordered in waves, which the kitchen was fine with. 

the only reason this wasn't a 5-star experience is that the room is small, crowded, dark, and noisy. we were literally reading the menus with the lights from our cellphones. the price of everything probably also weighs into my decision not to give the place 5 stars. for five of us to eat enough not to be starving but not to be totally full either was more than $300, and that includes one drink apiece.

this is one of my favorite places to eat in vegas. the first time i ate there last year in june during a conference and thought "i'd fly here to eat". then i went back the second night. i've been back twice since then and it doesn't disappoint. in the 4 times i've eaten there i've sat in the bar 3 times. i like the casual vibe and the waiter remembered me from months ago. 

we always start with the shrimp app that is deep fried and covered in deliciousness. i compare it to the bang bang shrimp at bonefish, but nobu's is better. 

we had the miso cod again, and it was even better this time. we also had several roles. i wasn't blown away with the yellow tail <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark>, but found the tempura shrimp very good. we got the <mark>Scallop</mark> in garlic sauce and they are incredible, soft, moist and the flavor is wonderful. i like to let the bar tender make some suggestions but the favorites are absolutely the shrimp, cod and <mark>Scallop</mark>. next time we will have to try something a bit different!

i came to nobu on my literal first night ever in vegas, and returned recently to discover that if anything, it's only gotten better with time.

on this visit we did a five-course chef's tasting menu that featured the signature dishes of the restaurant. 

my favorites were the delicate, flavorful <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> sashimi, crispy rock shrimp (which i devoured, despite not being a big shrimp eater), the restaurant's legendary, comforting and savory miso cod.

our server was passionate and knowledgeable about wine and sake pairings, and the service in general, all across the board, was impeccable.

nobu is a genre-defining restaurant, then and now.

if it were possible, i'd give nobu 4.5 stars. 

my sweetie and i spent a few days in las vegas this week and went out to high-profile restaurants every night.

all of the food we ordered was absolutely delicious, perfectly cooked and seasoned.  the sushi and sashimi were served at the perfect temperature, and everything tasted absolutely fresh.  

spicy miso chips w/scallop sashimi
squid pasta
miso-glazed black cod - (a nobu specialty and the best piece of fish i've ever eaten)
a selection of sashimi and sushi including yellowtail, fluke, salmon avocado roll, <mark>Yellowtail and Scallion</mark> roll.
flourless chocolate cake <mark>Bento Box</mark> - (as a pastry chef, i'm pretty wary of the whole "flourless chocolate lava cake" trend, but this one was fabulous, perfect texture and molten center,  served with white chocolate sauce and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. yum!)

i'd say the prices were quite reasonable as well.  keep in mind this -is vegas, people.  after checking out -many- of the restaurant menus in other hotels i'd say nobu was absolutely less expensive, and there's no way you're going to get better food quality.

the only half star missing would be for the quality of the service.  the clearing and mise en placing of the table was fabulous, but our waiter was a little too casual.  he seemed almost on the verge of <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> us as "guys" or calling my sweetie "boss".  nothing wrong with being friendly, but lets face it this isn't a diner.  a little more dignity would have been appropriate.  luckily, the professionalism of the runners made up for it.  

yay nobu!

i really wanted to try nobu after having an amazing experience at morimoto in philly.  i was not disappointed.  we arrived promptly at our reservation time and were seated immediately.  upon being seated we were greeted by our server within moments.    the atmosphere at nobu is much different than morimoto...nobu is more lively and trendy.  

they have you order a few dishes from the three parts of their menu.  we started with the oysters and the <mark><mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark></mark> which is served in lettuce wraps.  the lettuce wraps were quite good and the oysters were very earthy tasting. 

for our second course we chose the <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark> and the rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> in butter ponzu.  the <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark> may be one of the best dishes i've ever tasted in a restaurant.  at the end of our weekend i asked my brother in law what his favorite thing was about vegas and he responded without hesitation "eating <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark> at nobu."  not the club, not winning $300, not seeing old friends....the <mark>Creamy Spicy Crab</mark>.  

we chose 4 sushi rolls for our main course, the house roll which is like a rainbow row except the fish on the inside, a spider roll, unagi avocado (not on the menu but they happily prepared it for us) <mark>Yellowtail and Scallion</mark>.  each of the rolls was well prepared and the fish was fresh.

for dessert we ordered assorted mochi, which caused brother in law to wet himself for the second time that night.  our assortment included tiramisu, pistachio, honeydew, and raspberry.   all were amazing.

the service was outstanding throughout the night.  the meal was well paced, it wasn't the lingering three hour affair we had at morimoto but we didn't feel rushed at any point.  in the end i felt that the bill was actually fairly reasonable for what we ordered.  including tip and alcohol it came to about $90 a person.  i do have to <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> it did bother me slightly to find that some of the customers were wearing sneakers, open toe sandals (on men) and collarless shirts.  when i made our reservation they informed me that the dress code did not include these things, which is totally fine.  i'm all for getting dressed up to go out to eat, especially in vegas, and especially at a place like nobu, but i do not like it when i go through the effort and others don't have to.

nobu is my fave chain restaurant. this wasn't one of my fave locations. i feel the decor was not up to par with other locations such as nobu 57, nobu berkley or nobu in west hollywood. the food and service on the other hand are always top notch. they had my favourite wine (joh.jos. prum) which they seem to only have in 1/2 of their locations. the prices at this location seemed to be on the high side. $40 for 2 pieces of toro sushi, which is usually a staple for me but i decided to pass on it)

four of us dined at nobu on feb 28th. i was very disappointed in the quality, texture, and flavor of the seafood dishes. also, the waitstaff seemed rushed and it was extremely loud. those two elements combined made it a very chaotic ambiance. we ordered $400 (overpriced) worth of food and drinks. the following are dishes i had sampled.

i was in vegas this past weekend for a bachelorette party. and when we found out there was a nobu here (see my nyc review since i had been to that one quite a few times), we had to come! i was in charge of the ordering since no one else from the party had been there. 

the decor is similar to new york's nobu, but not as big and not as nice. the service is not as good but it's vegas so oh well.

we ordered:

peach martini and lychee martini - very good but strong.

<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> and ponzu sauce - this was fucking good. one of my friend's doesn't eat sashimi and she loved this dish. (see below for kristine n's review). they prepared it with about 20 pieces of sashimi on the plate for our big party! it was great!

<mark><mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> Salad</mark> - of course i had to order this! i love the salad dressing. 

miso black cod - the cool thing about nobu is that because we had a group of 8, they actually cut the fish in chunks and put them individually on little lettuce wraps so it would be easier to eat. this was fantastic and sweet.

chilean sea bass w/ mushrooms - the bride-to-be is a sea bass connoisseur and she said this was not chilean sea bass, but just regular sea bass. it was still very good though. yummm.

squid pasta - i love the squid pasta here. complimented w/ asparagus. i love asparagus!

rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> - we choose the butter sauce since the other sauces had been a bit spicy. yummy.

<mark>Bento Box</mark> - flourless chocolate cake with <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. this was better than i remembered from nyc. it's not flourless as in a chocolate bar on a plate - it actually does have a cake - souffle texture to it. it was great, and gooey in the middle. 

mango caramel ice-cream dessert - a light but tasty dessert with caramel bits in it.

one of the girls and i are not big seafood fans, but we loved all the dishes here. (see below for kristine n.'s review!) that tells ya something! everyone thoroughly enjoyed this meal which made me happy because i hoped they would trust my judgement in food. =)

it was nice because they brought out each dish one-by-one so you aren't stuffing your faces all at once. by the end of the dinner, we felt extremely satisfied but not so full we were going to explode.

yay, for nobu!!!

nobu is awesome. i've never been to a nobu before until this past weekend when i was in vegas for a bachelorette party. the decor inside the restaurant was pretty nice. service wasn't too bad, but it could have been a pinch better. felt like our waitress was spread out a little too thin and trying to cover too many tables, but when she was around, she gave us the time and explained things pretty thoroughly.

my favorite dish of the night was the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> (i normally don't like raw fish, but this one was freaking awesome!), <mark><mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> Salad</mark> (i normally don't eat fields of green salad, but this was an exception!), miso black cod (very yummy), the <mark>Bento Box</mark> dessert was great (esp the chocolate flourless cake which was very soft) and the mango caramel <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> dessert. the <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> was lighted flavored mango and there were caramel bits in there that was just great. probably my favorite dessert that i've ever had.

overall the food was fantastic. definitely would head back to nobu again next time i'm in vegas. they're opening one closeby and i'll be definitely dining there in the future.

if it were possible, i'd give nobu 4.5 stars. 

my sweetie and i spent a few days in las vegas this week and went out to high-profile restaurants every night.

the only half star missing would be for the quality of the service.  the clearing and mise en placing of the table was fabulous, but our waiter was a little too casual.  he seemed almost on the verge of <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> us as "guys" or calling my sweetie "boss".  nothing wrong with being friendly, but lets face it this isn't a diner.  a little more dignity would have been appropriate.  luckily, the professionalism of the runners made up for it.
