i don't know if it was because we were in vegas, but i felt like everything was a bit contrived.

*shrugs*

after being seated, our table was presented a single drink menu, and left alone for fifteen minutes. our waiter seemed a little miffed when he asked what we were going to start with to drink and i told him that we'd like to see food menus. i found it presumptuous and manipulative to leave us with a drink menu and that much free time. we are in vegas, i know, but when you're willing to pay for a nice meal, i expect a little more tact on behalf of the servers.

our waiter was also very quick to tell us how he thought we should move through the menu, all the while, mispronouncing common japanese dishes.

we tried a number of different dishes and rolls from the blue fin toro to <mark>Spicy Miso Chips <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark> or <mark>Scallop</mark></mark>, <mark>Fresh Water Eel</mark>, albacore, and <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>. everything was... good. not impressive, certainly not memorable... just good.

the interior of this location was bland. one of my co-workers mentioned that the decoration on the walls looked like large ironing boards, which was a fair assessment. the main dining area was too bright for a comfortable dinner, and had us sitting around the kind of small, wood topped table you might find yourself at while having lunch at your favorite sandwich shop.

the banana cake <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> cream <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> was a high note, although the spoonful <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> that they tried to pass off as a scoop made me feel like i was caught in a scene from american psycho. 

for all the noise i heard about nobu being something special, i left feeling uninspired, and with a reminder to myself why finding those one of a kind, family run japanese restaurants is such a treat.

if it were only about the sushi, nobu would get 5 stars from me. but, i knock off 2 stars for service. we walked in on a saturday night and got seats at the sushi bar, which is the place to be. we went with our sushi chef's suggestions, which were nobu's <mark>House Special</mark>, including "new-style sashimi." these consist of the best fish, <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark>, with delicate sauces and garnishes: <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, live octopus with a peruvian chili paste, whitefish and salmon <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce, tuna <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>-mustard sauce. everything was first-class, including the junmai daiginjo sake.

then, i ordered the <mark>Bento Box</mark> chocolate cake dessert. we were told it would take 8 minutes to cook. no problem - our bellies were happily full of sashimi. 20 minutes later, however, still no dessert, and we finally were able to flag someone down to check on it. another ten minutes went by. our waiter then came out to tell us there was a mixup in the kitchen and our cake went to another table. he tried to give us a plateful <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> to tide us over - this didn't go over well, as the last thing we wanted was to eat a plateful <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> and then a chocolate cake. another ten minutes or so, the dessert came out. it was excellent, but frankly wasn't worth waiting over half an hour for. we ask ed for the check while still eating...took another ten minutes...gave the credit card and another ten minutes went by...waiter came out to tell us the credit card isn't clearing and do we want to give another card? by this point, well over an hour had gone by since dessert was ordered and we just wanted to leave already. 

when our check finally arrived, they did charge us for the dessert that took over 30 minutes to arrive at our table. when i mentioned this to the server, he took it right off the bill. but i was miffed that i even had to ask - the right thing to do would have been to take it off in the first place.

too bad, since up until we ordered dessert we were very pleased with the sushi our wonderful chef served us. even for a saturday night in vegas, the service was unacceptably unresponsive for such a high-end restaurant.

i adore nobu! i go there every time i'm in vegas!

it is pricey, i spent $300 for dinner for two this past trip.....but it is sooooo worth it. 

my picks: 
-hamachi w/ jalapenos
-"live" octopus
-tiradito "live" scallop
-black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>
-kobe beef (try tataki style)
-<mark>Bento Box</mark> (chocolate cake with green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>)

though honestly, i've never had anything bad there. and try the nobu brand beer (made exclusively for them), i'm not a big beer drinker but it pairs really, really well with the food. 

the waiters are always excellent. they know the entire menu, so feel free to ask them for recommendations. 

if you have to pick one nice, expensive dinner in vegas.....definitely pick nobu.

the food here was amazing! we've heard about nobu from a friend of ours and decided to have our valentines dinner here. our waiter suggested 4-5 dishes for the both of us. so, we ordered the monk fish liver <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark>, tuna sashimi, salmon tartar, black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>, uni and an order of the <mark>Soft Shell Crab</mark> roll for the fiance who doesn't enjoy much raw dishes. the food and not to mention the presentation was incredible. we enjoyed each and every dish. for dessert, we picked the <mark>Bento Box</mark> which includes warm valrhona chocolate souffle cake, shiso syrup, white chocolate sauce and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> mmmmmmmmmmmmm. i'm so ready to go back and try more dishes on their menu.

before the concert started at the hard rock, i had enough time to sit down and have a fabulous dinner. at first i thought that steak might be a good idea, but i love asian food and wanted a great experience. my boyfriend and i walked into nobu, a japanese restaurant. for our first time there, we decided to ask for assistance with the menu, and chose several things from each part.

their menu is broken up by sushi, cold, hot and specialties. we decided to go with a little bit of everything.

our favorite was the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, and the crab tempura with their special sauce. their tempura shrimp and <mark>Vegetable</mark> were great also.

overall, for the price of 266 dollars for two people to eat out of a tasting menu, it was a great experience. i can't say much about their food because i have to say that i've eaten better tempura at our local asian restaurant, well being in the box.

although their tempura was okay (it was too soft and not crispy at all), their sushi was as close to the guam experience as we could get. it was sweet, done perfect, and the sauces were impeccable.

i honestly didn't feel that their tempura was worth the 200 dollar ticket. that was majority of our bill. i do believe that their signature <mark>Bento Box</mark> dessert was worth 14 dollars. it was creamy, a perfect souffle, and their green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> was just like home.

if you want something other than tempura for your experience at nobu, it's worth the price tag and the trip. for myself, a good japanese restaurant serves light, crispy, and fluffy tempura the way i've had it in japan and on guam from top japanese chefs. however, this was not the case, unfor<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark>.

i give this restaurant my personal 3/5 stars.

another wonderful iteration of nobu. having had this before at their honolulu location i had high expectations for this vegas experience. and i was not let down. although nobu is famous for their sushi i actually forwent having any and instead went for their superior and more unique hot and cold dishes. one constant stand out that i have had before is their blackened cod in butter lettuce cups. the varying textures and tastes are a perfect pairing. if you go you must ask for this as it is not on their menu. i also had the tempura fried rock shrimp in the creamy spicy sauce and again it was perfect, yummy, wow. 

for dessert we had the <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. and as you can read in my review of bubbies in honolulu it probably would've been just as good or better to have gone to whole foods afterwards and picked some up. still is was very good but not bubbies.

my only criticism is that this high style establishment is located in the hard rock. kinda feels a little out of place but either way anytime i'm back in vegas i will undoubtably be back.

amazing black cod. amazing. so, so good. the <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> tataki is my second favorite. if you're considering yellowtail, do the sashimi even of you're tired of ponzu and jalape\u00f1o. the yellowtail roll isn't as good. i mean, it's great, but i think the sashimi plate is a better deal with more flavor. like blair b. said, get the unique plates here.

as a side note, nobu participated in the taste of the nation, las vegas, which is a fundraiser to end childhood hunger in nevada. nobu cares about our community. i really appreciate that!

service at nobu is really out of this world.

nobu's <mark>Bento Box</mark> is my favorite dessert of all time, so much so that i replicate it at home with success--flour-less chocolate cake with green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> and hot fudge. lord have mercy i am in heaven!

if you have the money, spend it on nobu.

so we had reservations for 930 on a friday night and were seated immediately upon our arrival. the (almost all-male)staff were attentive, informative and friendly. 

our meal:

-edamame with shaved seasalt
-sashimi yellowtail <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> <mark>Yellowtail and Jalapeno</mark> (yummmmy, bobby's favorite)
-black cod in lettuce cups with filo flakes (my favorite, so perfect)
-sashimi <mark>Squid 'Pasta' with Light Garlic</mark> chips (little too salty)
-salmon sushi
-toro sushi (very tasty fish)
-dessert: edamame <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> atop a brownsugar brownie,caramel sauce, and tiny sliver of decadent brittle...the <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> scoop was so tiny that we really couldn't taste the edamame. 

a super treat for sushi, but be prepared to spend money!!

what can i say about nobu that hasn't already been written? asian fusion done right.  so many other places will attempt the same ideas, but they can not execute it like the nobu franchise can.

miso marinated black cod? delicious.  uni tempura? you can fry that? toro tartar with cavier? ok... stolen from keller... changed the salmon to toro, but decedent none-the-less. also, the best <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> i've had... anywhere...

i'll be honest. i came here for the dessert tasting platter. 

i saw the dessert list and died a little at the unique, creative and hitherto unknown creations being offered. so did my boyfriend. we decided we had to make it to nobu even if the apocalypse happened and giant flesh-eating gargoyles descended from the sky.

i did not plan to have a full meal at all but wouldn't you know it, i did. ahhh, i love when upscale japanese restaurants live up to the hype.

yellowtail with jalape\u00f1o: tender slices of my fish soulmate in an amazing soy yuzu sauce with just a little kick. most perfect dish ever.

beef tenderloin tabu yaki: not quite as tender as kobe (is anything?) but delicious nonetheless.

<mark>Spicy Scallop</mark> roll: fresh and tasty. the boyfriend was blown away by it, i thought it was good but otherwise unremarkable. i think raw scallop might be his yellowtail, though.

black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark>: their signature dish. it's really hard to find fault with it. tender, melt-in-your-mouth fish in a sweet, light sauce. it should be heavy, but it's not. that's the miracle of japanese cooking.

<mark>Spicy Seafood Soup</mark>: my favorite kind of food--soupy, spicy, seafoody. oh, and as an <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> bonus, loaded with more varieties of mushroom than a drug farmer. i have seen heaven and it's inside this bowl. get it!

now on to the nobu dessert platter:

<mark>Bento Box</mark>: flourless chocolate cake with a white chocolate sauce, shiso syrup and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. like a japanese molten cake. did i mention that molten cake is like edible carnal sex? well, it is. so get this. just don't go all matrix reloaded in the restaurant.

trio of mochi: lessee, we got pumpkin spice, strawberry, <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> flavor not known to man, stuffed with ice-cream and accompanied by sour japanese mountain peaches. mmm...

bananas in phyllo dough with tropical glaze: original creation not on the regular menu (haha!). it's crispy, fried bananas. need i say more?

harom<mark>Aji (Jackfish)</mark> in cinnamon and sugar and center is sweet potato pur\u00e9e: i totally didn't spell that right and since it's another original creation, i have no menu to look at. already tried googling and found nothing. anyway, this was incredible. i hate sweet potato and i thought this was da bomb. yeah, i'm channeling 2001 lingo.

eat here.

nobu i love you!!

came here on a vegas trip with one of the girls and this was our first stop! we dolled up, drove to the hard rock where there is valet parking, and walked into the center of the first floor where this ridiculously delicious restaurant is located.

service-great! everyone was really attentive. i always had my water filled, any finished dishes cleared off within the minute. the food came in really good timing as well. i was starving going in and i didn't have to wait. although coming from a restaurant like this i didn't expect anything less.

the decor is really comfy and not as fancy as i'd originally thought (or the other nobu restaurants apparently). you can definitely get away with begin pretty casual or dressing up your attire. while there were only small groups there they had some large tables <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> hidden rooms for even larger groups so if you need to bring a lot of people it seems as thought they'd be able to accommodate for more people.

now onto the best part of all! fooood is so worth the price!!
dessert: lemme start with this one because i cannot get over the delicious trio of soy caramel, miso apple cinnamon donuts and a really delicious home made <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> with toasted pecans. their pastry chef changes the dessert menu every season to go with what's in season which means i'm going to have to come here every season :)

apart from that we enjoyed the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>, eggplant miso (best i've ever had, decent portion but very rich), <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> (not spicy and very fresh!), <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> (the garlic chips <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> great texture but the citrus oil sauce was too overpowering) and the shiitake <mark>Mushroom Salad</mark> (very strong citrus vinaigrette but delicious mushrooms to make up for it)

awesome experience and a high price but definitely worth it :d

we stopped by nobu two nights ago and had a wonderful dinner.  we arrived and were seated at a booth....the decor of the restaurant was fairly trendy with an asian/bamboo wood theme.

based on the many yelp reviews we ordered the yellowfish <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, black cod w/ miso, <mark>Lobster <mark>Tuna <mark>King Crab <mark>Vegetable <mark>Salmon Nobu Style Taco</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark>, rock shrimp w/ 3 dipping sauces, the house sushi roll and the <mark>Bento Box</mark> desert (warm chocolate w/green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>).

each item was outstanding.....great unique flavors for each dish.  our favs were the black cod w/miso and the rock shrimp.  super yummy!

nobu rocks with a hit!

a cool michelin star restaurant in sin city!

my buddy and i went to nobu this past friday night at 9:30 for their omasake chef choice tasting menu. we had very few disappointments. they sat us right away at the bar, tables would have been 15 minutes even with our reservations.  lots of good energy in the restaurant, lots of japanese yelling back and forth from the waiters and sushi chefs.  we split a $50 bottle of nonfiltered very fragrant nigori sake cold which was smooth and easy to drink. the small bits of rice at the bottle of the bottle reminded me of red wine sediment as a good thing. 

the first course came out quick and cold. a chilled patty of toro tartar in a soy wasabi sauce topped <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark>, served with a baby silver spoon.  it was tender, smooth, rich and melt in your mouth.  the caviar was not memorable.  an a+ start and an expensive dish on their regular menu. next was 4 pieces per plate of thin cut fresh octopus topped with a cilantro leaf, a dot of super hot sauce, finished with citrus, like ceviche.  pretty good.  next was another cold appetizer of rice paper wrapped greens with a piece of raw ebi sweet shrimp, dressed with a fantastic sesame ginger sauce with a fried prawn head on the side.  my buddy especially liked the tempura batter on the <mark>Sweet Shrimp with Fried Head</mark> and the dressing.  i will personally come to your house and kill you if you do not eat the fried prawn head. 

then started the hot plates.  first was the ever famous <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> cod, a bit too sweet for my buddy but it did not keep us from both licking the plates.  a small piece of tender fish which just went on and on and kept melting in our mouths.  flavor of fish hard to come through past miso and sweetness.  like fish candy in a good way.  my friend said that an improvement would be to torch and crisp up the skin before putting on the sauce which would give some texture contrast and make the dish over the top.  $23 on the regular menu.  next was the beef tenderloin toban yaki style with a shitake and enokitake mushrooms and a piece of thin asparagus in a soy broth. beef very lean, not as melt in your mouth as i would like.  my buddy would have liked a nice piece of ribeye cap instead but who wouldn't.  the dish is served spitting hot on a mini hot plate and when they raise the cover in front of you, the steam envelopes you warmly.  try not to get the grease on you. 

next was the nigiri sushi course of 5 pieces along with a nice clam <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>. we got a piece of <mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> (mmmm), magura tuna (so tender), yellowtail (yum), clam (a bit tough) and <mark>Sea Eel</mark> which was the most tender fall apart <mark>Sea Eel</mark> i have ever tasted.  the sushi rice <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> fill you to the gills by that point and then they hit you with the dessert which was a bento presentation of a warm flowerless chocolate lava cake with lots of lava and very little cake and a very good not sweet green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>.   this just put the nail in the coffin.  we were stuffed, but we couldn't stop eating since it was so good.  

the restaurant closed at 11pm on a friday night, but we will remember the meal for a long time coming.  next time i'm in vegas i plan to make it a point to return and see what the chef choice is at that point in time.  this was the $100 omasake.  the $150 would have <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> some kobe beef and <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> and there.  we were very happy with our choice.  i think the meal was an absolute bargain for the price.

went for the first time.  

hot food: tried the sea bass w/ miso sauce, teriyaki tasmanian sea trout skewers (very similar to salmon), <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>.  all very very good, especially the bass and trout. 

sushi: fish was the freshest around.  however, i was very disappointed with the lack <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>.  i asked my sushi chef for anything unique that they do with their sushi.  got a blank stare.  i'm used to the unrelated and not-so-famous nobu's in solana beach, ca where creativity is more common than not, and what a difference it makes.  

service was incredible.  it felt as if they are standing behind you waiting for your every need.  i suppose you have to order off the specials if you want something creative (non-sushi), but you'll be paying a premium $30 to $75+ per plate.

should be a 4 to 4.5 star, but since i had high expectations that weren't met, i'm docking my rating by a point.

let me preface this review by saying that i'm a huge self-admitted sushi <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> and my husband is peruvian, so nobu seemed a logical choice for our 7th anniversary dinner.  aside from the villainous penny slots  just outside the door, it was the perfect choice. 

we started out with the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>.  yellowtail is by far my favorite raw fish and i've had a similar dish at several excellent bay area restaurants, but this was by far the most flavorful rendering of this dish that i've had. the sashimi was also not razor thin which was an awesome <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> bonus (honestly, i've gotten use to the fact that fine dining, particularly in vegas, means small portions and high prices so the amount of fish was a pleasant surprise. 

next, we tried the tiradito nobu style <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> type of halibut like fish.  now, here the fish was razor thin, but came out with a dot of rocoto, a block of rock salt, the traditional lime juice and a side of cilantro.  my husband says this is exactly what tiradito is supposed to taste like, which makes me want to spend significantly more time in peru.  it was amazing.

we then moved on to the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> next and honestly, this was the only part of the meal that i was underwhelmed by.  i know that this is supposed to be the signature hot dish at nobu, but i've had a very similar dish at both morimoto napa and at hyakumi at cesar's palace and the texture of the fish wasn't the melt in your mouth awesomeness that i have come to expect from the dish. the flavor was right on, and if i'd never had black cod before, i would have loved it.  

so, we moved back to the cold dishes and tried the <mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> salmon sashimi (<mark>White Fish <mark>Scallop <mark>Salmon <mark>Oyster <mark>Beef <mark>Yuba Sashimi New Style</mark></mark></mark></mark></mark></mark> because it's served with ginger, <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> other amazing deliciousnesss that i can't recall right now), finishing off the savory with the toro green onion maki (cut).  they were both amazing. 

what shocked me was how incredibly amazing the two <mark>Dessert</mark> we had were.  we tried the <mark>Bento Box</mark>, a flourless chocolate cake with house-made green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, and this peach cobbler like dish with almond miso crumble and ginger <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>.  i don't know if anyone else finds some green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> to sometimes taste vaguely like lipstick, but this <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> was delicate and a beautiful companion to the rich chocolate cake.  the warm peaches with the crumble and (again not overpowering) ginger <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> was a highlight of my whole trip to vegas.  (and i'm not really a dessert person)

okay, this review is way too long, and i didn't even mention the impeccable service.  i can't wait to go back and wish there was a nobu in the bay area.

this is, quite simply, the best food that i have ever eaten. i come here every two years for a packaging convention and i try to make nobu a treat for my key employees. it is expensive, to be sure, but the food is so worth it. 

this is not a "slap on the feed bag joint".  it is meant to be enjoyed over a couple of hours.  the plates are small but are meant to be shared with friends. you should order a few plates so that each bite is savored and you get to try multiple kinds of food. hot and cold dishes with a japanese/peruvian flair. 

cold sake in a bamboo pitcher and shot glasses. 

we had a few cold dishes...salmon, oysters, edamame, and a couple more.

hot dishes of <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> cod, sea bass, <mark>Scallop</mark>.....

<mark>Bento Box</mark> flowerless chocolate cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, a peach dish and an apple donut plate that was beyond belief. 

great ambiance, service and food. a delicious treat.

nobu is like a foodie dream come true. first off, the ambiance was lovely---the noise level was definitely on the high side but i didn't mind. we had a group of 5 people so we ordered several small plates. we started off with two cold dishes: oysters and <mark>Yellowtail Belly</mark> special. hot dishes: <mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> and kobe beef gyoza. and different varieties of sushi afterwards. you really can't go wrong with any of these. the <mark>Dessert</mark> were truly a revelation and the perfect way to end the meal: yuzu panna cotta with raspberry mango caviar and raspberry sorbet; flourless chocolate molten cake with green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>; and the miso brioche/apple donuts with caramel sauce. i won't bother using any adjectives like "delicious" or "amazing" because i think the descriptions speak for themselves. end of story.

went there in the summer to celebrate boyfriend's birthday. of course, we had the omakase... 

key points:
- the exotic fish sashimi and tartar were very very good, because they were usually combined <mark>Yellowtail or Salmon <mark>Blue Fin <mark>Toro Tartare</mark> with Royal Ossetra Caviar</mark></mark>. fresh too... duh... 
- black cod. signature!!! yummy!!! although to be honest, i think it could be a little too sweet for certain individuals. 
- yellow tail w/ jalape\u00f1os. interesting testing. def something new for me!
- kobe beef... whatever. 
- sushi. really??? ok... don't ever go to nobu for the sushi. it's not even real japanese rice or freshly made wasabi!!!! 
- best best best warm chocolate lava green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> cake ever!!!!

btw, the bill was around $350. no complains whatsoever.

conclusion: must go before you die. or before your taste buds die.

holy crap, the food here was so good!  we had all different kinds of dishes - sashimi, hot dishes, various lettuce wraps, etc., and everything was so tasty.  they even made us some dishes that weren't on the menu that my friend requested from the matsuhisa menu.  

the service was also great - they explained all the dishes as they came out and kept our water glasses full.  

the one thing i was not a fan of was the flavored fruity sakes.  they tasted like fruit roll ups or jam, and they were just not very pleasant.  i did however enjoy my peruvian caipirinha, and would recommend that.  also enjoyed a couple sips of my friend's johnny blue, but when is that not the case?  

had <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> for dessert, and they had some awesome flavors you can't find elsewhere like red velvet.  

it's weird that my first nobu experience was in vegas, given that i live in la, but now i'm excited to check out the nobus near home!  :)

simply amazing best ever!!!   i struggled to give it 5 stars, i think i would call this a 4.5 star rating.   its a little overpriced for what it is, they need to do more food, i left hungry.  that shouldnt happen.  service 98 out of 100.  food 95 out of 100  value 80 out of 100.   i think it was a little overpriced, but the quality was totally there!   i would definitely go again, and i think i would love it again, but it let me down just a little, after hearing all the hype.   i could go here once , or go to sushi mon 4 times, all i can eat, you know my choice on that one if i want sushi 4 times!   

after the sticker shock, which i didnt pay so i dont care what it costs, the food was insanely good.  we had the saki, beers, and a feast of sashimi, shrimp, <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>, and rolls.   my favorite was the lettuce wrapped black cod, oh my god, this was the best fish bite i have ever had.  it melted in your mouth like butter from the fat and the protein - i am not sure if it was oil pan fried, or what, it was hot, but not too hot, but it had a little sizzle on it, and the glazed oil on it just <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the silky flavor.  i would go back there just for that!   the desert was a rhubarb molten love with <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> over it, talk about yummy!   tasted like strawberries to me, but it was perfect, i would have taken one more scoop <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, next time i will ask.   i am sure they would accommodate.     5 star food at 5 star prices.    

decor was a little drab to me, i dont know what it was, it was classy, but too dark, the bamboo was nice, but i think they could use some live fish tank in the place, maybe i missed something, the walkway in was nice, but the dining room was a little drab for me.  i think a splash of color would have been nice.   anyway, i am nitpicking now and thats not fair to them.    quality stuff, incredible food, great dining room, great location at hard rock.  highly recommended.  please bring your wallet, or someone elses, you will need it!     also, be prepared for a late night snack later meal after, unless you are on a diet.    4.5 star overall, i likey!

i must admit, i have not been to a nobu that i didn't like.  so yes, i am a fan of this high-end japanese chain restaurant.  we had dinner here this past friday night.  unfor<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> i am not fond of the hotel that it's located in... which is barely a step up from a hooters-type ambiance with the class-less tatted out clientele and their hoochie mama's attached to their hips.  well back in the day hard rock was the place to go to... but that was years ago.  so the fact that one has to step foot into the hard rock casino to get into the entrance of this restaurant... should really get a minus star for not strategically relocating this at a more ritzy hotel casino like bellagio or cosmopolitan.   

we started off with cocktails... lychee martini and a greyhound... can't go wrong there.  as for the app...started off with the sea salted warm edemame.  i was so hungry, i practically ate all the soy beans.  i ordered the yummy <mark>Kelp Salad</mark> and he ordered hamachi sashimi with jalepeno... so perfectly fresh <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark> sauce or miso... so good!  he ordered the <mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> was sinfully delicious... (fried so not a healthy choice).  and i ordered the chilean sea bass with dried miso... my all time favorite, which did not disappoint!  salmon, hamachi and unagi sushi... small but still so good.  and we ended with yet another cocktail :-) and the <mark>Bento Box</mark>.... flourless chocholate cake with white chocolate sauce and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>... omg!  amazing dinner with outstanding service.  yes nobu is expensive but i was for<mark>Tuna (Big Eye)</mark> that he was so generous... so not really sure what our bill was... but so worth every bite.

i have been to the nobu miami beach, nobu at atlantis (bahamas) and the multiple nobus in nyc countless times. i have to admit, i held out on the nobu vegas because it was in the hard rock...silly, i know.

nobu is so fabulously consistent, i love it. our order:

-lychee martini
-sake
-wagyu dumplings
-edamame
-salmon sashimi
-yellowtail jalepeno roll
-miso black cod (favorite)
-rock shrimp (second fav)
-<mark>Colorado Lamb Chops</mark> (best bite, exclusive to the vegas location, and wow are they good)
-dessert: <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> and chocolate cake

the restaurant was busy for a random tuesday night but service was very good. i really liked our waiter. he recommended the <mark>Colorado Lamb Chops</mark> and i'm glad he did. all the food was delicious. 

yes, as other yelpers mention, nobu is pricey (for 2 of us our bill was just under $350) but the food, service and ambiance were great.

definitely coming back soon xo

7/2: nobu hard rock rivals yellowtail @bellagio as my all-time favorite restaurant. i've been here one previous time and i don't remember much, but nothing bad. i just kept comparing it to my favorite, which is kind of unfair. however, this time was different...very memorable in a good way. 

my server gordon and his waitstaff team's service was amazing! i had the locals tasting menu ($75) and it was worth every penny. every dish was cordially described in just the right amount of detail before being served. all questions were answered in a friendly manner. the atmosphere was very nice and classy as well. beautiful decor. 

-kobe beef taco (as an appetizer, separate from tasting menu)...best taco ever! beef was soft and moist

-<mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark> (best sashimi i've ever had by far! so soft and fresh. price tag aside, i could go for 10 of these plates! though that might be too much of a good thing)
-tuna <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark> (love it. best tuna ever) 
-rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> with creamy spicy (best shrimp ever...you're getting the point! i didnt know shrimp could taste this good) 
-<mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> (this and the yellowtail sashimi were my favorite dishes...high praise for these 2 seems to be the trend based off of many reviews. definitely no disagreement here. best fish ever! if you are ordering one item, i highly recommend it) 
-assorted sushi and <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark> (basics but pretty good. large <mark>Scallop</mark> were <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the soup. unique taste and interesting twist compared to standard <mark><mark>Lobster <mark>Miso Soup</mark></mark></mark>. delicious!) 
-dessert (strawberry, vanilla, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>)...all were great. not really a complaint, but a variety of <mark>Dessert</mark> is preferred. im sure they would be amazing like everything else as well.

thank you nobu, for one of the best dining experiences ever. i will definitely be back!

several different nobu locations worldwide and the us. this nobu is located inside hard rock hotel - the first one in vegas (and the better one). i had one of my birthday celebrations here.

we got <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>, <mark>Nobu Crispy Rice with Big Eye Tuna</mark> tataki <mark>King Crab with Amazu Ponzu</mark>, chocolate banana martini, lychee martini, <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>, <mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> sauce, <mark>Tenderloin of Beef</mark> toban yaki, nobu's <mark>House Special</mark>, <mark>Salmon Skin</mark> handroll, kulfi and my birthday "<mark>Bento Box</mark>".

sashimi and <mark><mark>Nobu's Moriawase Sashimi Salad</mark></mark>:
the fish here is generously cut.  they're fresh and the sauces they come with accent the fish. 5/5

<mark>Shrimp or <mark>Scallop</mark> with Wasabi Pepper or Spicy Garlic</mark> sauce:
if you like garlic and a little bit of spiciness - this is the dish for you.  the garlic sauce was amazing. the dish comes <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> mushrooms. 5/5

<mark>Tenderloin of Beef</mark> toban yaki:
came in a sizzling plate. a piece of very tender and juicy steak with enoki mushrooms <mark>Tuna (Big Eye) and Asparagus</mark>. simple but delightful dish. 5/5

nobu's <mark>House Special</mark>:
salmon, tuna, hamachi, avocado and crab meat  wrapped in nori and daikon, sprinkled with masago. each of the 6 pieces are not-so-bite-sized. 4/5

<mark>Salmon Skin</mark> handroll:
<mark>Salmon Skin</mark> with just a very thin layer of salmon meat making each piece so crispy and delicious. that's all that matters in a <mark>Salmon Skin</mark> handroll. 5/5

kulfi:
chocolate pistachio frozen custard, nobu cabernet cherries, candied pistachios, chocolate feulletine.  great textures: crispy and creamy. 5/5

<mark>Bento Box</mark>:
flourless chocolate cake, white chocolate sauce, shiso syrup and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. i'm not sure why it's called a <mark>Bento Box</mark> since it definitely doesn't come in one. it was free and yummy. 4/5

excellent food, great ambiance. how did it get stuck in the hard rock?

the yellowtail and jalape\u00f1o rolls were very good, and the <mark>Bento Box</mark> finished the meal perfectly. we did swap out the green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> for milk ice. and it was good!

this is a review of the groupon deal dinner.

the skinny: fusion peruvian japanese dishes left me unimpressed (3) service: excellent service despite the disappointing cuisine (5) value: for the groupon, it is still overpriced for what it is. so you can imagine what i have to say about full price ... not worth it (2.5).

so here's the deal. we spotted the nobu groupon for $95/2 person (regularly $150) prix fixe menu and we thought "how can we pass this up?".

we went and were seated prompty. our server was great at giving us time and space to make some decisions on the menu. we ended up getting in <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the prix fixe an order of their <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> to round out the menu. the specials that they offered didn't really appeal - there was a lot of fruit/candied nuts mixed in with sashimi which sounded overly sweet to me so i passed on those.

starting <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> simple edamame with maldon sea salt (love those flakes!), it was a nice way to start a meal.

course 1) <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>/cilantro (6 slices): this was a good dish but not exceptional. although i have had different versions of this before, this is one of the better renditions given the quality of the fish and the strategically correct amount of heat. my only thing with this dish was the actual slices of sashimi itself - the slices were a bit thin and ragged along the edges which surprised me given the supposed caliber of this place.

course 2) selection of nigri (6 pcs) and a california roll (6 pcs): the nigri was okay - the slices of fish were decent sized. i was despondent when i realized that the sushi rice was a little too overcooked and sticky.

course 3) rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>: the first bite was good however as we ate, the spicy aioli began to slowly permeate the batter leading to a soggier batter. i think it aioli would have been better served as a dipping sauce rather than dressed on the tempura to retain textural integrity. flavorwise, this was a nice dish and we loved the mixture of chive and togarashi.

course 4) miso glazed black cod: candied black cod more like it! overly sweet, the piece of fish was smothered in the sugary sauce which became more unappetizing the more we worked to finish this. i have made this at home using his recipe with 1/2 the sugar and it is much better.

course 5) <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark> (<mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> to the groupon): the tempura was okay nothing special. the batter was slightly spongier than what i like. i think it would have been better if the shredded daikon/ginger was provided to us so we could <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark> much/little we wanted.

course 6) normally this would be <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> except it was my birthday so i got a molten cake with a tiramisu and green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. all of them were very good however there was nothing that really wow'ed me to think that it was exceptional.

perhaps 10 years ago, the level of this fusion cuisine would be considered cutting edge. however time has made his dishes appear quite dated. the signature dishes of rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>/yellowtail jalape\u00f1o sashimi/miso glazed black cod are easily found elsewhere - one might argue that this location's rendition is rather lackluster considering the price. given the many issues with the dishes mentioned above, i cannot recommend this place given the groupon price let alone full price. although our server was truly exceptional, that doesn't make up for the food. 2.5 rounded up to 3 starred review.

i loved my food here! please see pics of my appetizer and dessert.
the service was wonderful from beginning to end. i had salmon wrapped pear as an appetizer. it was sprinkled with olive oil. very fresh, light and refreshing!
to drink...a lychee martini. it was good
for my main course, i ordered the black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> sauce. it was scrumptious! it was flaky and flavorful. i would order this again.
i just couldn't go to a japanese restaurant and not get sushi...so i order yellowtail with jalape\u00f1o. it was the right amount of spicy.
dessert...flourless chocolate cake...side of house made green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> garnished with blueberries and raspberries. phenomenal!
my only complaint is that it was extremely pricey. but i would still return!

my boyfriend had just been telling me that we should try eating at nobu, so when i saw a groupon for this place the next day we couldn't pass it up.

we bought the $95 groupon ($150 value) which included a five-course tasting menu for two. my favorite was the first dish, their signature yellowtail sashimi with jalape\u00f1o. i do agree with other reviewers who said the sashimi was a bit thin, but wow did it taste great. the dessert dish was a close second favorite. it included a molten chocolate cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>, and a whiskey-infused cappuccino-like dessert. my least favorite was the assorted sushi dish that included a california roll and six pieces of nigiri (tuna, salmon, and snapper). every other dish was unique and full of flavor, while this assorted sushi dish was average at best.

aside from the five-course meal, we also ordered their popular cucumber martini. it was a strong little drink with a fantastically fresh aroma. i don't often love the scent of alcohol but this drink was a definite exception.

we had a very satisfying experience overall. although slow at times, the service was great and every dish was thoroughly explained. the manager was also quite nice and stopped to speak with us for a moment.

we weren't entirely stuffed by the end of our five courses, but we were full enough. overall, the food-tasting was a true experience and definitely worth a try, but this isn't a place i would frequent due to their notably high prices. to sum up my review - if you're into high quality japanese tapas-like dishes and can easily afford the heady price point, this place is for you!

i would give this place a million stars, but it only goes up to 5.  my husband and i were staying at the hard rock hotel & casino on our honeymoon, and received a gift card to nobu, at our request, from my sister-in-law.  i've heard nothing but good things, and they were all true.  we chose the omakase menu option.  we had 9 courses each, and the dessert came with three different items, for each of us.  we spent just under $400 after the tip for both of us, and it was worth every penny.  the service and food was absolutely impeccable.  our server was amazing.  the manager came out to our table personally and presented us with the gift card my sister-in-law had purchased prior, over the phone.  he also provided us with complimentary glasses of champagne.  i am terrible at naming cuisine that i don't normally eat, so can't remember specifically all items we had, but for certain, the yellowtail tartare w/ caviar, the <mark>Mushroom Soup</mark>, the black cod w/ miso, the wagyu beef and the chocolate molten cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> and cappucino <mark>Dessert</mark> were so delicious.  i have not one bad thing to say about the food or service at this place.  nobu at the hard rock is a gem in the middle of a loud and crazy city.  this meal was the highlight of our dining experience on our week-long honeymoon in vegas.  i would eat here every single day if i could.

impromptu trip to vegas for my best friend's birthday! yay! while planning our trip, i noticed a groupon for nobu. i'd been wanting to try out one of the la locations for a while, so this seemed like a win-win. overall, the experience was pretty great. the service was friendly and very attentive (almost too attentive... my ice tea cup was never empty. i don't think they even let it get half empty...)

the meal started with edamame which wasn't anything special. standard at any japanese place you'd go to. the first course was the yellowtail sashimi with jalepeno. this was so good!! i'm normally not a jalepeno fan, but it had just the right amount of kick to it. this was definitely my favorite dish of the night.

next up was the rock <mark>Shrimp and <mark>Shojin Vegetable Tempura</mark></mark>. this was alright. i liked the sauce with the lettuce/salad below, but it was too heavy for the shrimp... my friend and i agreed that it just left us craving honey walnut shrimp from panda express. 

third entree up was the <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark>. this was also an outstanding dish, like the yellowtail. the fish was cooked perfectly and the entire dish was both presented well and tasted great. 

the fourth entree (and the reason for docking one star) was california roll and assorted nigiri. maybe it's just because i live in la and i'm spoiled by great sushi, but i wasn't impressed. the fish was fresh enough, but definitely not up to par to say, sugarfish. and at the heart of it all, nobu is a japanese restaurant, so i expected their sushi to be on par with their fusion dishes. sadly, not the case.

the meal ended with the <mark>Bento Box</mark> dessert, which had flour-less chocolate cake, green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> <mark><mark>Tasmanian Ocean Trout</mark> with Crispy Baby Spinach and Yuzu Soy</mark> cappuccino thing. i'm not a huge dessert person but it was ok. i've never disliked any green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> i've had and the cappuccino thing was unique. 

overall, it was a great meal and good experience. without a doubt, it was worth the price of the groupon. not sure about full price though. i think only the yellowtail sashimi and <mark>Black Cod Miso</mark> would be worth it.

acclaimed celebrity chef nobu matsuhisa has a restaurant in every continent. 
 there are two high end sushi joints here in vegas. this location not as swanky as the one in caesars palace  nevertheless is a signature restaurant for the hard rock hotel and a little more casual than 35 steaks next door.
the elegant dining room with bamboo thrown in the ceiling and minimal d\u00e9cor in a zen sort of way it's warm and inviting. 
to start the yellowtail sashimi was superb, delicate sensuous .the crispy tempura rock shrimp drenched in a yuzu spicy sauce over salad greens was tangibly <mark>Add Lobster 1/2</mark>. the picture of the black cod in miso should be posted as the wikipedia definition of umami simple, savory and sweet accented by a pickled ginger shoot. the sushi was ordinary but respectable fresh. a nice little green tea <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark> for dessert to complete the nobu experience. the staff were friendly professional rock stars.
if you want to feel like a baller the groupon deal is the way to go and you be treated to a nice multi-course adventure by one of japan's best chef. 
kampai.

i have always wanted to try nobu and finally went! and it was worth the wait let me tell you! we went for my bday and did not have a reservation. we got there pretty early around 5ish so they were able to sit us without a res. our waiter jeffrey was on point. best service. he recommended we start with the <mark>Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno</mark>. it was melt in my mouth amazing. i could live off the dish for the rest of my life. lol. it was yellowtail with the right amount of sweetness and spice. we also got the cucumber salad which was pretty good. a lot of the vinegar did go to the bottom of the bowl which made it hard to coat your salad but it was still good. we also had a sear salmon sashimi which i do not remember the name that was excellent. we got spicy edamame, <mark>Beef Kushiyaki</mark>, the black cod <mark><mark>Japanese Red Snapper</mark> <mark>Spinach Salad with Dry Miso</mark></mark> and the wagyu beef gyoza. the cod was really good and highly recommended. the wagyu beef was great with two dipping sauces. we literally could have kept ordering food. we had a couple of nice cocktails as well. 

after dinner they brought us out a plate with happy birthday with a choc cake and green <mark>Assortment of Mochi Ice Cream</mark>. we also ordered the whiskey moose. both <mark>Dessert</mark> were to die for and i was in heaven. 

what a fun place to go. you have people dressed to the max, casual people, people from all over the world that come and eat here. come chow down some amazing eats, listen to some funky music and watch the beautiful people. yes please!

my second time dining at nobu and once again it was great. some of the best sushi in vegas . the waiter was amazing . he was very knowledgable and recommended some great options. the yellowtail sashimi was great, we had to order 3 servings. the eel roll was great. we ordered a filet that came out in a covered sizzling skillet and it was cooked to perfection . the manager came and greeted us at the table and brought 3 <mark>Dessert</mark>. the banana <mark>Ice Cream or Sorbet</mark> was great. i'll be back next time i'm in town
